summary: This is a 2019 federal court opinion and order addressing motions in a civil case brought by Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 against the United States. The document details the background of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, the secret negotiation and execution of a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) in 2007, and allegations that the U.S. Attorney's Office violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act by failing to consult with victims. This document is part of a court filing (likely a motion for summary judgment or related pleading) detailing the timeline of events surrounding the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office. It focuses on disputes over victim notification under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA), revealing efforts by Epstein's defense team to delay or limit notifications and the government's internal communications about its legal obligations. This is a court order (Document 435) from the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, granting partial summary judgment to Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2. The court finds the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims. The order details the legal standards and reasoning, concluding the government's actions deprived the victims of their statutory rights.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure accused of sexually abusing more than 30 minor girls from 1999-2007. The document details the federal investigation and the secret 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement that resolved his federal criminal liability.

persons.context: One of the two petitioners. The court rejects the government's contention that she is not protected by the CVRA, stating there is no dispute Epstein sexually abused her while she was a minor.

events.title: Palm Beach Police Complaint
events.description: The Town of Palm Beach Police Department received a complaint from parents about the sexual abuse of a 14-year-old girl by Jeffrey Epstein, leading to the identification of approximately 20 minor victims.

events.title: FBI Investigation Opened
events.description: At the request of the Palm Beach Police, the FBI opened an investigation into allegations that Epstein and his assistants used interstate commerce to induce minors into illegal sexual activities.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Provides Information to FBI
events.description: Jane Doe 1 provided information about her abuse and Jane Doe 2's abuse to the FBI.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Signed
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida formally entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution.

events.title: FBI Agents Meet with Jane Doe 1
events.description: FBI Special Agents met with Jane Doe 1 to explain Epstein's guilty plea to state charges and the compensation process, but did not fully disclose that the NPA had already been signed.

events.title: Government Sends Draft Victim Letter
events.description: The Government sent an email to defense attorney Lefkowitz attaching a draft victim notification letter dated for the next day, explaining the NPA and victims' rights to attend state sentencing.

events.title: Defense Objects to Victim Notification
events.description: Defense attorney Lefkowitz sent a letter to U.S. Attorney Acosta objecting to sending victim notification letters before Epstein's plea or sentencing.

events.title: Starr Objects to Victim Letters
events.description: Defense attorney Kenneth Starr sent a letter to Acosta objecting to the victim notification letters and claiming it was inappropriate to send them without defense review.

events.title: Misleading FBI Letters Sent
events.description: The FBI sent letters to Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 stating the case was 'under investigation,' not disclosing the existence of the NPA that had already been signed.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Meets with FBI and AUSA
events.description: Jane Doe 1 met with FBI Agents and an AUSA, provided additional details of abuse, but was not told about the already-negotiated NPA.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to state law solicitation of prostitution charges. This plea was part of the federal NPA resolution, but victims were not adequately informed of the connection.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Files Emergency CVRA Petition
events.description: Jane Doe 1 filed an emergency petition for enforcement of her rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

events.title: Victim Notification Letters Finally Sent
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent victim notification letters to Jane Doe 1, Jane Doe 5, and other identified victims, explaining some civil compensation provisions but not the full NPA.

events.title: Motion to Release NPA
events.description: Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 filed a motion seeking release of the full Non-Prosecution Agreement.

events.title: Government Letters to Victims
events.description: The U.S. Government sent letters to victims (including Jane Doe 1 and 2) counseling 'patience' with the investigation, even though it had already bound itself to the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein.

events.title: Signing of Epstein NPA
events.description: The U.S. Government entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims, a central event leading to the CVRA violation.

events.title: Court Grants Partial Summary Judgment on CVRA Violation
events.description: Judge Kenneth A. Marra grants Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2's motion for partial summary judgment, ruling the U.S. Government violated their rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

locations: United States District Court, Southern District of Florida
West Palm Beach, Palm Beach County, Florida
keyFacts: From about 1999 to 2007, Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused more than 30 minor girls at his Palm Beach mansion and elsewhere.
A secret Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) was signed on September 24, 2007, granting Epstein and unnamed potential co-conspirators immunity from federal prosecution.
The U.S. Attorney's Office did not consult or confer with any of the identified victims about the NPA before it was signed, a potential violation of the Crime Victims' Rights Act.

Epstein's defense team, particularly Jay Lefkowitz, actively sought and received assurances from prosecutors that the NPA would be kept confidential and that victims would not be notified without their input.

The NPA identified 34 confirmed minor victims and included a provision for Epstein to pay for an attorney to represent them in a civil compensation process, while requiring them to waive other damage claims.

Epstein's defense team, including attorneys Kenneth Starr and Lilly Ann Sanchez, repeatedly objected to and sought to delay victim notification letters required by the Justice for All Act of 2004 (CVRA).
The U.S. Attorney's Office, under Alexander Acosta, directed prosecutors to delay notifications to accommodate Epstein's defense team's review, as shown in a November 2007 letter to Starr.

Victims, including Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2, received letters from the FBI in early 2008 stating the case was 'under investigation,' deliberately omitting that a Non-Prosecution Agreement had already been signed in September 2007.
Victims' attorney Bradley Edwards was not informed of the NPA's existence when he contacted prosecutors in June 2008, and was led to believe federal charges could still be filed.

The government acknowledged in a December 2007 letter that its investigation showed Epstein's criminal conduct dated to at least 2001, meaning all identified victims were minors at the time of the offenses.

The court ruled the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims, Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2.

The government concealed the existence of the NPA from the victims and misled them to believe federal prosecution was still possible, even sending letters asking for 'patience' after the agreement was signed.
The court rejected the government's argument that Jane Doe 2 was not a protected victim under the CVRA, stating unequivocally that Epstein sexually abused her while she was a minor.
The violation occurred because the government bound itself to the NPA before notifying victims, depriving them of any opportunity to provide input or affect the prosecutorial decision.
The court's ruling is on the liability (the violation itself); the issue of an appropriate remedy for the CVRA violation was deferred for later proceedings.
